Developer Guide¶

Module Overview¶

entrance¶

preprocess¶

Module: unpack Module for unpacking DICOM files

MRIphantom_desktop.src.preprocess.unpack.dicom_to_nifti(source_folder: Path, target_folder: Path, name=None)¶

Converts folder of dicoms into a nii.gz file.

segmentation¶

Module: process

This module provides functions for processing images and analyzing marker data.

MRIphantom_desktop.src.segmentation.process.count_difference(ct_path, mri_path, save_path)¶

Counts differences between CT and MRI markers and saves statistics.

This function calculates differences between marker coordinates from CT and MRI images. It computes various statistics such as mean difference, minimum difference, maximum difference, standard deviation, and the number of differences exceeding certain thresholds (0.5 mm and 1 mm). The results are saved in JSON files for overall statistics and per-slice statistics.

Parameters: - ct_path: A string specifying the path to the pickle file containing CT marker coordinates. - mri_path: A string specifying the path to the pickle file containing MRI marker coordinates. - save_path: A string specifying the directory where the statistics JSON files will be saved.

Returns: - params: A dictionary containing overall statistics. - distances: An array containing all computed differences between CT and MRI marker coordinates. - slice_distances: A dictionary containing per-slice statistics.

MRIphantom_desktop.src.segmentation.process.get_coords(markers_path)¶

Retrieve coordinates of markers from a specified pickle file.

This function reads the pickle file located at the given path and extracts the coordinates of markers. The pickle file should contain a 3D numpy array representing marker coordinates. Each marker is represented by its x, y, and z coordinates.

Parameters: - markers_path: A string specifying the path to the pickle file containing marker coordinates.

Returns: A list of lists, where each inner list represents the coordinates of a marker in the format [x, y, z].

MRIphantom_desktop.src.segmentation.process.isolate_markers(threshold_gen, save_path, interpolation=False)¶

Isolates markers from thresholded images and saves their coordinates.

This function isolates markers from thresholded images generated by the threshold_gen generator. It applies filtering and morphological operations to extract markers from the images. The coordinates of the isolated markers are saved into a pickle file.

Parameters: - threshold_gen: A generator yielding thresholded images. - save_path: A string specifying the path where the marker coordinates will be saved. - interpolation: A boolean indicating whether interpolation is applied (default is False).

Returns: None

MRIphantom_desktop.src.segmentation.process.perform_thresholding(img_gen, is_mri=False, interpolation=False)¶

Performs thresholding on images generated by img_gen.

This function applies thresholding techniques to the images yielded by the img_gen generator. It calculates the threshold values based on whether the images are MRI or CT, and optionally applies interpolation. Thresholded images are yielded as output.

Parameters: - img_gen: A generator yielding images for thresholding. - is_mri: A boolean indicating whether the images are MRI (default is False). - interpolation: A boolean indicating whether interpolation is applied (default is False).

Yields: Thresholded images as numpy arrays.

MRIphantom_desktop.src.segmentation.process.slice_img_generator(input_file, interpolation=False)¶

Generates slices from a 3D image file.

This function generates 2D slices from a 3D image file (e.g., .nii file). It loads the image file and yields each slice after processing, including intensity normalization and resizing.

Parameters: - input_file: A string specifying the path to the input image file. - interpolation: A boolean indicating whether interpolation is applied (default is False).

Yields: 2D slices of the image as numpy arrays.

Build Instructions¶

To build the MRIphantom application using PyInstaller and an app.spec configuration file, follow these steps:

Install PyInstaller: If you haven’t already installed PyInstaller, you can do so via pip by running the following command:

$ pip install pyinstaller

Use the app.spec Configuration File located in the rood directory of the project: The app.spec file is used by PyInstaller to specify how the application should be bundled.

Run PyInstaller: Once you have checked the app.spec file, you can use PyInstaller to build the application by running the following command in your terminal or command prompt:

$ pyinstaller app.spec

Locate the Executable: After PyInstaller completes the build process, you can find the executable file in the dist directory within the project folder. The exact location may vary depending on your operating system and the configuration specified in app.spec.

Test the Application: Before using the application, it’s a good idea to test it to ensure that it functions correctly. Run the executable file generated by PyInstaller to verify that the application works as expected.

Debugging¶

A special Debug Mode is enabled by exporting system variable DEBUG=2:

$ export DEBUG=2

Debug Mode disables splash screen and other excessive functionality.

Style Guide¶

General¶

Line length: Preferably keep lines shorter than 100 characters. Always keep lines shorter than 120 characters. Markdown (.md) files are excluded from this restriction, to allow editing the text without worrying about line breaks.

Toolkits and libraries¶

Pylint Flake8 Python style guide

Python¶

Follow the MRIphantom Flake8 configuration. Imports: - Standard library imports - Related third party imports - Local library specific imports

Docstrings¶

Include docstrings for each class, method and function. Keep the comments up to date. Use the # TODO comment to mark code parts that should be revisited. Use the # FIXME comment to specify parts of code that should be fixed.
